question.name: 43.1.3.2 Adequacy of fit
question.questiontext:
Adequacy of fit

We now know that the variance \( V(Y \lvert x) = \sigma^2\) is the key to describing the adequacy of fit of our simple linear model. In general, the smaller the variance, the better the fit although you should note that it is wise to distinguish between `poor fit' and a large error variance. Poor fit may suggest, for example, that the relationship is not in fact linear and that a fundamental assumption made has been violated. A large value of \( \sigma^2\) does not necessarily mean that a linear model is a poor fit. It can be shown that the sum of the squares of the errors say \(SS_E\) can be used to give an unbiased estimator \( \hat{\sigma}^2\) of \( \sigma^2\) via the formula \[ \hat{\sigma}^2 = \dfrac{SS_E}{n-p} , \] where \(p\) is the number of independent variables used in the regression equation. In the case of simple linear regression \(p = 2\) since we are using just \(x\) and \(c\) and the estimator becomes: \[ \hat{\sigma}^2 = \dfrac{SS_E}{n-2}. \] The quantity \(SS_E\) is usually used explicitly in formulae whose purpose is to determine the adequacy of a linear model to explain the variability found in data. Two ways in which the adequacy of a regression model may be judged are given by the so-called Coefficient of Determination and the Adjusted Coefficient of Determination.
